data.title: Uncaught TypeError: this.promptToSaveItem(...).then is not a function
data.body:
[Enter steps to reproduce:]

1. ...
2. ...

**Atom**: 1.19.0 x64
**Electron**: 1.6.9
**OS**: Mac OS X 10.12.6
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught TypeError: this.promptToSaveItem(...).then is not a function

```
At /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane.js:709

TypeError: this.promptToSaveItem(...).then is not a function
    at Pane.module.exports.Pane.destroyItem (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane.js:709:52)
    at Pane.module.exports.Pane.destroyActiveItem (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/pane.js:683:18)
    at Workspace.closeActivePaneItemOrEmptyPaneOrWindow (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/workspace.js:1703:48)
    at HTMLElement.core:close (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/register-default-commands.js:233:38)
    at CommandRegistry.module.exports.CommandRegistry.handleCommandEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/command-registry.js:265:35)
    at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/command-registry.js:3:65
    at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.dispatchCommandEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:610:22)
    at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.handleKeyboardEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:401:28)
    at WindowEventHandler.module.exports.WindowEventHandler.handleDocumentKeyEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/window-event-handler.js:100:42)
    at HTMLDocument.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/window-event-handler.js:3:65)
```

### Commands

```
     -0:02.1.0 core:close (input.hidden-input)
```

### Non-Core Packages

```
atom-beautify 0.30.4 
atom-html-preview 0.1.22
```

data.title: 1.19.0 fails to build on Ubuntu 14.04 32 & 64 bit (failed at superstring@2.0.10 install script 'node-gyp rebuild')
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Not applicable - Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Not applicable - Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Not applicable - Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Not applicable - Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Trying to build Atom 1.19.0 on Linux (tested on Ubuntu 14.04 32bit and 64bit) using ``script/build``, the following error is displayed:
```
npm WARN deprecated minimatch@2.0.10: Please update to minimatch 3.0.2 or higher to avoid a RegExp DoS issue
npm WARN deprecated graceful-fs@2.0.3: graceful-fs v3.0.0 and before will fail on node releases >= v7.0. Please update to graceful-fs@^4.0.0 as soon as possible. Use 'npm ls graceful-fs' to find it in the tree.
npm WARN deprecated minimatch@0.2.14: Please update to minimatch 3.0.2 or higher to avoid a RegExp DoS issue
npm WARN deprecated minimatch@0.4.0: Please update to minimatch 3.0.2 or higher to avoid a RegExp DoS issue
npm WARN deprecated minimatch@0.3.0: Please update to minimatch 3.0.2 or higher to avoid a RegExp DoS issue
npm WARN deprecated to-iso-string@0.0.2: to-iso-string has been deprecated, use @segment/to-iso-string instead.
npm WARN deprecated jade@0.26.3: Jade has been renamed to pug, please install the latest version of pug instead of jade
npm WARN prefer global typescript@1.4.1 should be installed with -g
npm WARN prefer global jasmine-node@1.10.2 should be installed with -g
../src/onig-string.cc: In constructor ‘OnigString::OnigString(v8::Local<v8::String>)’:
../src/onig-string.cc:30:43: warning: comparison between signed and unsigned integer expressions [-Wsign-compare]
   hasMultiByteChars = (value->Length() != utf8_length_);
                                           ^
../src/core/text-buffer.cc: In constructor ‘TextBuffer::Snapshot::Snapshot(TextBuffer&, TextBuffer::Layer&, TextBuffer::Layer&)’:
../src/core/text-buffer.cc:748:56: error: invalid initialization of non-const reference of type ‘TextBuffer&’ from an rvalue of type ‘<brace-enclosed initializer list>’
   : buffer{buffer}, layer{layer}, base_layer{base_layer} {}
                                                        ^
../src/core/text-buffer.cc:748:56: error: invalid initialization of non-const reference of type ‘TextBuffer::Layer&’ from an rvalue of type ‘<brace-enclosed initializer list>’
../src/core/text-buffer.cc:748:56: error: invalid initialization of non-const reference of type ‘TextBuffer::Layer&’ from an rvalue of type ‘<brace-enclosed initializer list>’
make: *** [Release/obj.target/superstring_core/src/core/text-buffer.o] Error 1
gyp ERR! build error 
gyp ERR! stack Error: `make` failed with exit code: 2
gyp ERR! stack     at ChildProcess.onExit (/home/andrei/atom/atom-1.19.0/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/node_modules/node-gyp/lib/build.js:276:23)
gyp ERR! stack     at emitTwo (events.js:106:13)
gyp ERR! stack     at ChildProcess.emit (events.js:191:7)
gyp ERR! stack     at Process.ChildProcess._handle.onexit (internal/child_process.js:215:12)
gyp ERR! System Linux 3.16.0-69-generic
gyp ERR! command "/home/andrei/atom/atom-1.19.0/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/bin/node" "/home/andrei/atom/atom-1.19.0/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/node_modules/.bin/node-gyp" "rebuild"
gyp ERR! cwd /home/andrei/atom/atom-1.19.0/node_modules/superstring
gyp ERR! node -v v6.9.5
gyp ERR! node-gyp -v v3.4.0
gyp ERR! not ok 
npm ERR! Linux 3.16.0-69-generic
npm ERR! argv "/home/andrei/atom/atom-1.19.0/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/bin/node" "/home/andrei/atom/atom-1.19.0/apm/node_modules/atom-package-manager/node_modules/npm/bin/npm-cli.js" "--globalconfig" "/home/andrei/.atom/.apm/.apmrc" "--userconfig" "/home/andrei/.atom/.apmrc" "install" "--runtime=electron" "--target=1.6.9" "--arch=ia32"
npm ERR! node v6.9.5
npm ERR! npm  v3.10.10
npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE

npm ERR! superstring@2.0.10 install: `node-gyp rebuild`
npm ERR! Exit status 1
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Failed at the superstring@2.0.10 install script 'node-gyp rebuild'.
npm ERR! Make sure you have the latest version of node.js and npm installed.
npm ERR! If you do, this is most likely a problem with the superstring package,
npm ERR! not with npm itself.
npm ERR! Tell the author that this fails on your system:
npm ERR!     node-gyp rebuild
npm ERR! You can get information on how to open an issue for this project with:
npm ERR!     npm bugs superstring
npm ERR! Or if that isn't available, you can get their info via:
npm ERR!     npm owner ls superstring
npm ERR! There is likely additional logging output above.

npm ERR! Please include the following file with any support request:
npm ERR!     /home/andrei/atom/atom-1.19.0/npm-debug.log
```


### Versions

Tested using Ubuntu 14.04 (both 32bit and 64bit), using nodejs installed from the official node Ubuntu repository (package version  6.11.2-1nodesource1~trusty1).

```
$ apm --version
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 ia32
python 2.7.6
git 1.9.1
```

The complete npm-debug.log is available here: https://paste.ubuntu.com/25275549/

data.title: [1.19.0] [macOS] Atom CLI doesn't open native tabs
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom CLI doesn't open native tabs.
It used to be working on 1.18.x just fine.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Navigate to a project, and do `atom .`
2. Navigate to a second project and do `atom .`

**Expected behavior:** Single Atom window with two native tabs.

**Actual behavior:** Two Atom windows.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

macOS: 10.12.6
Atom: 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome: 56.0.2924.87
Node: 7.4.0
apm: 1.18.2

### Additional Information

macOS Dock settings:  
Prefer tabs when opening documents: `Always`

Atom Core / Title Bar option: `native`

data.title: Atom crashing on Windows 10 , requires constant clear window state.
data.body:
Safe mode does nothing. Require to launch clearing window state. This same problem was happening on OSX. 

I am not certain yet but the editor on Windows is screwing line feeds in git client. Its not inserting unknown characters anymore and breaking building javascript files in Linux subsystem like it did before however.

data.title: TextBuffer::onDidReload never fires for external changes
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

`TextEditor::onDidReload` appears to not be firing, at least within the 10 second timeout of package specs.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Check out [`linter-eslint@8.2.1`](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/tree/v8.2.1)
2. Run the package specs
3. Note that [two](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/blob/v8.2.1/spec/linter-eslint-spec.js#L241) [specs](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/blob/v8.2.1/spec/linter-eslint-spec.js#L285) are failing.

**Expected behavior:**

`TextEditor::onDidReload` fires when the file is reloaded due to the external process changing the file.

**Actual behavior:**

The specs are expecting [a notification](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/blob/v8.2.1/spec/linter-eslint-spec.js#L92-L95) that the fix was complete from ESLint (which triggers), as well as Atom declaring via `TextBuffer::onDidReload` that it has finished reloading the file after the external ESLint process has finished changing the file [here](https://github.com/AtomLinter/linter-eslint/blob/v8.2.1/spec/linter-eslint-spec.js#L82-L87).

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

```
Using Atom version:
Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
Using APM version:
apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.11
git 2.13.0
```

Tested on Windows 10 x64, and Ubuntu 14.04 x64.

### Additional Information

Possibly related to the problem in https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14189, likely caused by https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/14435.

This is a regression from Atom v1.18.0, where these specs worked properly.

data.title: [v1.19.0] unconfirmed text of CJK IME collapse to one character
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Unconfirmed texts inpute by CJK IME collapse to one caracter.
Same issues were reported by Microsoft/vscode#24557, Microsoft/monaco-editor#320
This kind of issue might come from specific versions of electron/electron or older versions of chrome.
You can view GIFs describing the following example at the above known issues (Microsoft/vscode#24557, Microsoft/monaco-editor#320).

### Steps to Reproduce

Type some CJK texts like あいう (keystrokes `a -> i -> u` produce this; this example is Japanese) without pressing ENTER key.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Show あいう with underline (as usual for Japanese input).

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Show last character only, in this case う.

Please refer GIFs on Microsoft/vscode#24557 and Microsoft/monaco-editor#320.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

Unfortunately it occurs always.

### Versions

- macOS: 10.12.6
- Atom: 1.19.0
- Electron: 1.6.9
- Chrome: 56.0.2924.87
- Node: 7.4.0
- apm: 1.18.2

data.title: Update document with electron version
data.body: Update document for recommend version to major update (v1.X.Y)

data.title: 1.19, Linux: Middle-clicking an unsaved tab causes entire desktop to be unresponsive to clicks
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I'm on Ubuntu 16.04. Atom 1.18.0 was fine, but since updating to Atom 1.19.0, if I have a file with unsaved changes and I try to close the tab by middle-clicking on the tab, then a modal pops up (Are you sure you want to close the file without saving?), but I can't click on anything. The cursor doesn't change no matter what I hover over and no clicks register on the modal's buttons or even other (non-Atom) windows. Clicking another window doesn't focus it, bring it to the front, or get any reaction.

My computer is still responsive to keyboard inputs, though even if I alt-tab to another window, nothing reacts to my mouse still. I have to press escape on Atom's closing-confirmation modal or otherwise close it before anything reacts to my mouse again.

If I close the file tab in any other way (clicking the X button, or pressing ctrl-w), the modal and my mouse work perfectly normal. With little non-web UI experience, I'd guess the issue has to do with some kind of blocking call (like the modal) happening or a lock being hogged improperly during the middle-click event handler.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Be on Ubuntu 16.04 (?)
2. Open Atom, open a file in Atom, and make some changes to the file without saving.
3. Middle-click on the file's tab.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

My mouse to work as usual: for the modal to be clickable, and to have the ability to click on other windows freely even while the modal is still open.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

See description.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%, tested with safe mode and a new ~/.atom directory too.

### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
$ cat /etc/lsb-release 
DISTRIB_ID=Ubuntu
DISTRIB_RELEASE=16.04
DISTRIB_CODENAME=xenial
DISTRIB_DESCRIPTION="Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS"
$ uname -a
Linux canyon 4.4.0-89-generic #112-Ubuntu SMP Mon Jul 31 19:38:41 UTC 2017 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

data.title: 1.19.0 版本,当一文件关闭后再打开不能维持之前的折叠状态,1.18.0版本是可以的
Question : Does the new Github/Git feature contain an api or SCM provider ?
data.body:
Greetings,

It would be great to provide a package that also adds support similar to the Git integration for other SCM providers such as `hg` and `svn`. 

However I was not able to locate a package that contains the Git part of the feature.

data.title: 1.20.0-beta0 unable to load on Windows
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

Note that clearing the state would fix this issue, but the issue should still be fixed in some other way.

### Description

Can't open projects from the previous version of Atom Beta

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install 1.19 beta 7
2. Open a project, some tabs, and the About page (maybe the Settings View too)
3. Update to 1.20 beta 0 automatically (Squirrel should download the update and you need to Restart and Install once it's downloaded)
4. Reopen Atom once the update completes (the error should happen automatically)
5. If the error doesn't appear, open a project from `File > Reopen Project`

Note that if you manually add a project with `Add Project Folder` or open a project you had already opened in 1.20 the issue doesn't appear

**Expected behavior:** Projects should open in tree view and tabs should be restored

**Actual behavior:** Instead, the error pop-ups and no editor is opened

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

This happened when updating to 1.20.0 beta0 on Windows 10 x64

```
> apm --version

apm  1.18.3
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.13.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

### Additional Information
Stack trace:
```
Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: Cannot read property 'node_modules\about\styles\about.less' of undefined
    at ThemeManager.module.exports.ThemeManager.loadLessStylesheet (C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\theme-manager.js:294:65)
    at ThemeManager.module.exports.ThemeManager.loadStylesheet (C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\theme-manager.js:271:27)
    at C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\package.js:545:60
    at Array.map (native)
    at Package.module.exports.Package.loadStylesheets (C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\package.js:543:65)
    at C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\package.js:137:23
    at Package.module.exports.Package.measure (C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\package.js:99:21)
    at Package.module.exports.Package.finishLoading (C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\package.js:133:25)
    at PackageManager.module.exports.PackageManager.loadAvailablePackage (C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\package-manager.js:521:38)
    at C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\package-manager.js:479:25
    at Config.module.exports.Config.transact (C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\config.js:321:22)
    at PackageManager.module.exports.PackageManager.loadPackages (C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\package-manager.js:473:25)
    at C:\Users\nano0\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.20.0-beta0\resources\app\src\atom-environment.js:810:34
```

My settings can be found on this [Gist](https://gist.github.com/Positive07/623ef49857e10c67eabc8ba93f68ae22)

data.title: Generate AppImage for Linux
data.body:
Someone from the atom team please see below, solve the remaining issue and then merge this once it builds "green".

This PR, when merged, will compile this application on [Travis CI](https://travis-ci.org/) upon each `git push`, and upload an [AppImage](http://appimage.org/).

It tries to mirror 1:1 what the debian pipeline is doing, using the same binaries. So __this should _not_ add additional burden to the Atom team__. It is merely a self-mounting filesystem image. Think of it as putting the contents of the deb into a self-mounting ISO.

Providing an [AppImage](http://appimage.org/) would have, among others, these advantages:
- Applications packaged as an AppImage can run on many distributions (including Ubuntu, Fedora, openSUSE, CentOS, elementaryOS, Linux Mint, and others)
- One app = one file = super simple for users: just download one AppImage file, [make it executable](http://discourse.appimage.org/t/how-to-make-an-appimage-executable/80), and run
- No unpacking or installation necessary
- No root needed
- No system libraries changed
- Works out of the box, no installation of runtimes needed
- Optional desktop integration with `appimaged`
- Optional binary delta updates, e.g., for continuous builds (only download the binary diff) using AppImageUpdate
- Can optionally GPG2-sign your AppImages (inside the file)
- Works on Live ISOs
- Can use the same AppImages when dual-booting multiple distributions

[Here is an overview](https://github.com/probonopd/AppImageKit/wiki/AppImages) of projects that are already distributing upstream-provided, official AppImages.

__I need help on the following issue:__  What translates the lowercase `--create-debian-package` to make `if (argv.createDebianPackage)` in `script/build` trigger? I _think_ I have added and am calling `--create-appimage` but I am currently getting

> Skipping creating AppImage. Specify the --create-appimage option to create it.

Any help greatly appreciated.

AppImage developers are on #AppImage on irc.freenode.net.

data.title: Folding with soft wrap enabled doesn't update text editor view correctly as of 1.19
data.body:
### Prerequisites

- [x]    Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
- [x]    Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
- [x]    Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
- [x]    Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
- [x]    Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
When folding text using `editor:fold-at-indent-level-2`, the visual representation of some of the folds is not updated correctly

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open [this file](https://github.com/calebmeyer/git-links/blob/f5100a252734bc4b4de55dcc4b85b743d456d551/lib/git-links.coffee)
1. Run `editor:toggle-soft-wrap` to enable soft wrap if it is not already on
1. Run `editor:fold-at-indent-level-2` using the command palette

Size of the Atom window may be related /cc: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15190#issuecomment-322209970

**Expected behavior:**
Each element at the second level of indentation is folded, and shows as folded

**Actual behavior:**
Some (or none) of the elements are showing as folded.
Moving the cursor with the arrow keys navigates inside the fold
Moving the cursor with vim-mode-plus `hjkl` navigates over the fold

**Reproduces how often:**
I am able to see the problem in safe mode about 80% of the time. Almost always, at least one fold gets folded correctly, sometimes two. Very rarely all folds will show correctly.

### Versions
Windows 10 creator's update
`atom --version`
Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
`apm --version`
apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.13.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015

### Additional Information
Screenshots:
My configuration:
![mine](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3342777/29088025-8273c790-7c3d-11e7-9744-4fda97adbe34.png)

Safe Mode
![safe](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3342777/29088034-89210670-7c3d-11e7-8fa7-8d14888a8c93.png)

data.title: key-mappings with `alt` don't suppress Mac OS composition characters anymore (atom-1.19)
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Shortcuts with alt don't suppress Mac OS composition characters.

### Steps to Reproduce

With `ABC - Extended` keyboard layout:

1. `Open Your Keymap`
2. Add the following keymaps:
```
# general
'atom-text-editor':
  # use jkl; vim-like when pressing alt (word by word, paragraph by paragraph)
  # or alt (letter by letter)
  'alt-h': 'core:move-left'
  'alt-j': 'core:move-down'
  'alt-k': 'core:move-up'
  'alt-l': 'core:move-right'
```
3. save
4. try to use them

With `US` keyboard layout /cc https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15189#issuecomment-321503095.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

A GIF from atom-1.18

![atom-1 18](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/927609/29082497-f96e7ebc-7c65-11e7-913e-9f6d394c2d36.gif)


**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

A GIF from atom-1.19

![atom-1 19](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/927609/29082512-04686558-7c66-11e7-8016-8fbe979c1da3.gif)


**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

Always.


### Versions

* **Atom:**       1.19.0-beta7
* **Atom-Shell:** 
* **OS:**         Mac OS X 10.12.5
* **Misc**
    * apm  1.18.2
    * npm  3.10.10
    * node 6.9.5 x64
    * python 2.7.10
    * git 2.11.0


### Additional Information

Probably only happens on Mac OS.

When I installed the atom-autocomplete-php an error appears to me, how can I specify the absolute path of composer and php?

Either PHP or Composer is not correctly set up and as a result PHP autocompletion will not work. Please visit the settings screen to correct this error. If you are not specifying an absolute path for PHP or Composer, make sure they are in your PATH. Feel free to look package's README for configuration examples

data.title: [from v1.19] highlight decoration node can be re-rendered which cause keyframe animation restart.
data.body:
### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description This issue started from v1.19 which use new editor-rendering with etch. CC @as-cii #### Short summary From v1.19, highlight decoration node is re-rendered in it's lifetime which cause keyframe animation unwillingly re-started. This was not issue in v1.18 where highlight decoration node was stable in it's lifetime. See, each removal of brackets-matcher's highlight cause fadeout animation re-started. Which is because highlight node of `class=t9md-test-flash` is re-created at that timing. ![decoration-node-unstable2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/155205/29040638-b6cee3ce-7bea-11e7-9aa3-4168238b2b6d.gif) ### Detail When highlight decoration is created by `editor.decorateMarker`, corresponding `
` node is created at top of LinesComponents. Child nodes of this div represent actual decoration style. - Till v1.18 these nodes are stable in its lifetime. - From v1.19 with new editor-rendering, these nodes can be re-rendered during it's lifetime. This is not problem when highlight class is simply set `background:` color. But it's become problem when highlight class specify animation. Lets' say - I have set decoration which `class=flash-anime` which will be destroyed after 1.0 sec - `flash-anime` css class have keyframe animation which fadeout flash during 1.0 sec. - When Atom re-render(re-create) this decoration node within 1.0 sec, it cause re-start fadeout keyframe animation. - This issue is more likely to happen when brackets-matcher involved, which create/remove decorations and it cause existing highlight node in the same LinesComponents **re-rendered**. GIF: Animation in 10sec is separated into three because of re-render of highlight node. GIF: style recalculation highlight decoration re-created which cause animation restart. ### Steps to Reproduce I can reproduce this issue with safe-mode. 1. Prepare sample.txt and custom-style. - sample.txt `{a: 1}` - style.less ```less @keyframes t9md-test-animation { from { background-color: #5b91c8; } to { background-color: transparent; } } atom-text-editor .t9md-test-flash .region { animation-name: t9md-test-animation; animation-fill-mode: forwards; animation-duration: 10.0s; animation-iteration-count: 1; } ``` 2. Open sample.txt, place cursor at first line. 3. Paste following code in chrome-dev-tools console. This code does. - highlight inner range of `a: 1`(inner range of curly brackets). - marker will destroyed after 10sec. - highlight class is `t9md-test-flash` which fadeout background color in 10sec. ```javascript (function flashreproduceIssue() { const editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor() const cursorPosition = editor.getCursorBufferPosition() const scanRange = editor.bufferRangeForBufferRow(cursorPosition.row) editor.scanInBufferRange(/{.*?}/, scanRange, ({range}) => { const innerRange = range.translate([0, +1], [0, -1]) const marker = editor.markBufferRange(innerRange) editor.decorateMarker(marker, {type: "highlight", class: "t9md-test-flash"}) setTimeout(function () { marker.destroy() console.log("destroyed"); }, 10000); }) })() ``` 4. Within 10sec, move cursor left/right to cause add/remove brackets-macher's highlight. And see how keyframe animation is re-started because of re-creation of highlight node. **Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen] Node used for highlight decoration is stabled(not re-rendered). **Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] Node used for highlight decoration is re-rendered, cause keyframe animation re-started. **Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?] 100%. ### Versions ``` Atom : 1.19.0-beta7 Electron: 1.6.9 Chrome : 56.0.2924.87 Node : 7.4.0 ``` ### Additional Information I use fadeout flash effect with keyframe animation a lot in [vim-mode-plus](https://atom.io/packages/vim-mode-plus) to give feedback to user. E.g. when yank inner range of brackets, flash inner bracket range. From v.1.19 cursor move cause brackets-matcher's highlights add/removal which cause vmp's flash effect re-started unwillingly.

data.title: language-java: the "new" keyword on the same line as the literal string ":" breaks syntax hightlighting
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The literal string ":" on the same line as a "new" keyword breaks the syntax highlighting in language-java. The first " of ":" seems to be treated as not starting a string, while the second actually starts the string. Everything else following the second " of ":" is then highlighted as a string.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. New file
2. Paste the following minimal code
~~~ java
class My class {
  private static void foo(String text) {
    System.out.println(new Timestamp(System.currentTimeMillis()) + ": " + text);
  }

  // This is rendered as a string
}
~~~

**Expected behavior:** The literal ": " should be rendered as a string

**Actual behavior:** The text starting with `" + text` and ending with the last `}` in the buffer is rendered as a string. The first quote does not appear to be highlighted as part of a string, and the colon : seems to be treated as an operator.

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the times

### Versions

Atom 1.18.0
apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.6.2.windows.1
visual studio

Running on Windows 7 Professional

### Additional Information

n.a.

data.title: Fix regression re: closing tabs via middle mouse click on Linux
data.body:
Fixes atom/tabs#461
Fixes atom/tabs#52

---

On Linux, when the user performs a middle-button mouse click, Chromium fires both a `mousedown` event *and* a `paste` event. This PR teaches the `TextEditorComponent` to ignore the `paste` event.

When the user performs a middle-mouse click on a tab, we first get the `mousedown` event. In response to that event, we [close the tab and attempt to prevent Chromium's default processing for the event](https://github.com/atom/tabs/blob/ce1d92e0abb669155caa178bb71166b9f16f329a/lib/tab-bar-view.coffee#L416-L418). This prevents Chromium's default processing for the *`mousedown`* event, but then Chromium also fires a *`paste`* event, and that event pastes the clipboard's current content into the newly-focused text editor. 🤦

#14987 removed some of the middle-button mouse click handling related to pasting on Linux. This PR restores that logic and the related tests. (See `TextEditorComponent::didMouseDownOnContent(event)`.) With that change in place, since Atom already has its own logic for handling pasting, we shouldn't need to handle browser `paste` events. By ignoring the browser `paste` events on Linux, this PR fixes atom/tabs#461.

### TODO

- [x] Fix atom/tabs#461
- [x] Add test for `TextEditorComponent::didPaste(event)`
- [x] Address TODO in `TextEditorComponent::didPaste(event)` (https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/15183#discussion_r131672090)

### Test plan

- [x] Test on Ubuntu:
  - [x] Verify fix for https://github.com/atom/tabs/issues/461
  - [x] Verify the previous fix for https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8648 is still intact
- [x] Test on macOS: Verify that the ctrl-click behavior fixed in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/14987 is still intact

data.title: Blurry text when scrolling down on Windows7 with display scaling for 1.19.0
data.body:
This issue is still inside the latest beta7, the text is blurred if scrolled down with mouse on Windows7 with display scaling, and still blurry when stop scrolling. But it will clear again if you scroll up with one step. No issue for static text.
No such issue in 1.18
Scaling: "Control Panel\Appearance and Personalization\Display" to set to 115%

data.title: Test spec progress got very slow from v1.17.0-beta0.
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

As far as I noticed, from Atom v1.17.0-beta0, test spec take very long time compare to previous version.

This is comparison when I run same `it` clause with `null` body 1000 times by loop.

- v1.16.0: 35.48s
- v1.17.0-beta0: 149.73s <== slow
- v1.19.0-beta7: 134.54s <== still slow

I noticed this issue while I investigating following `vim-mode-plus's spec take very long time from v1.17` issue.
I thought it's vim-mode-plus's issue and postponed investigation till now since I didn't see noticeable problem in daily Atom use..
https://github.com/t9md/atom-vim-mode-plus/issues/754

### Steps to Reproduce

1. create sample `test-spec.coffee` under `spec` dir(whichever package is OK) and run spec by `Window: Run Package Specs`.

```coffeescript
fdescribe "slow down", ->
  for n in [1..1000]
    it "case-a", -> null
```

2. See progress of spec to pass gradually slow down.

## Result of 1000 empty spec run.

- v1.16.0: 35.48s
- v1.17.0-beta0: 149.73s
- v1.19.0-beta7: 134.54s

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Progression of test doesn't slow down.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Progression of test doesn't slow down gradually.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%.

### Versions

- v1.16.0: No problem

```
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

- v1.17.0-beta0: First version I noticed this slow down

```
Atom    : 1.17.0-beta0
Electron: 1.3.14
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

- v1.19.0-beta7: Latest beta I can still see slow down issue.

```
Atom    : 1.19.0-beta7
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Atom crash at launch
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I have downloaded the last beta version of atom 1.19.0-beta7 and when I launch for the first time Atom it doesn't display anything. After checking the console, it display some errors. (check screen in Additional information)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Download atom 1.19.0-beta7
2. Launch atom Beta on Mac OS Sierra 10.12.6 (16G29)

**Expected behavior:** Display welcome tab in atom

**Actual behavior:** Nothing display, just empty window

**Reproduces how often:** Always
